Šest let je minilo, kar je padel njegov dom
5. novembra 2013 je Darko Kuzmič ostal brez strehe nad glavo, rušenja so se nato končala.
05 Nov 2019, 06:50 by Boštjan Fon



Rušenje se je pričelo točno ob 13. uri. FOTO: Boštjan Fon



Darko Kuzmič terja 100.000 evrov odškodnine. FOTO: Boštjan Fon



Danes ni sledu o bungalovih, ki jih je postavila rajnka država. FOTO: Boštjan Fon



Darko Kuzmič pred svojim domom dan pred rušenjem. FOTO: Boštjan Fon



Protestnike je odgnala policija. FOTO: Boštjan Fon


RIBČEV LAZ – Pred točno šestimi leti, 5. novembra 2013, ob 9. uri so se inšpekcijske službe ob podpori policijskega kordona usmerile do skromne lesene hiške na naslovu Ribčev laz 63 ob bregu Bohinjskega jezera. Začelo se je najbolj znano rušenje doma, objekta, ki je bil edino prebivališče Darka Kuzmiča. Ta mu je bil dodeljen, ko je bil postavljen za vodjo adaptacije doma Zveze socialistične mladine Slovenije (ZSMS) v Bohinju, danes Centra za šolske in obšolske dejavnosti (CŠOD). Hiška je na tem mestu stala od leta 1965, poleg nje še 10 enakih bungalovov, ki jih danes več ni.


Darko Kuzmič terja 100.000 evrov odškodnine. FOTO: Boštjan Fon

Darko Kuzmič hiške ni zgradil samovoljno, brez dovoljenj, temveč je objekte zgradila tedanja država. Zdajšnja država, ki se je rodila iz tiste, ki je Kuzmiču namenila streho nad glavo, se je odločila, da bo objekt, ker da je črna gradnja, čeprav jo je postavila predhodnica in ne v bohinjskem koncu živeči Prekmurec, porušila.Kot zanimivost: prav v tem spornem bungalovu, ki je bil porušen na današnji dan pred šestimi leti, je pred Kuzmičem prebival direktor hotela. Kuzmič je dva dneva pred svojim 60. rojstnim dnevom postal še en socialni problem na sončni strani Alp.


Darko Kuzmič pred svojim domom dan pred rušenjem. FOTO: Boštjan Fon

Brez razumevanja občine Bohinj bi pred zimo moral dobesedno pod bližnjo veliko smreko, tako pa so mu dodelili stanovanje v stari šoli na Gorjušah, kjer prebiva še danes. »Lahko bi šel res samo še pod smreko, a zaradi novega objekta še te ni več tam,« bizarnost celotne zadeve opiše Kuzmič. Takoj po osamosvojitvi je plačal takratnih 250.000 tolarjev, saj je mislil, da bo lahko s tem uredil papirje in odkupil hiško. Tako pa je danes že šesto leto brez nje.


Danes ni sledu o bungalovih, ki jih je postavila rajnka država. FOTO: Boštjan Fon

Na ljubljanskem okrožnem sodišču trenutno poteka pravda, v kateri Kuzmič od države in sedanjega CŠOD zaradi zrušitve objekta zahteva 100.000 evrov odškodnine. Kuzmič je prepričan, da mu brunarice ne bi smeli porušiti, ker je bila njegov dom. »Vedeli so za odločitev evropskega sodišča za človekove pravice s področja nelegaliziranih gradenj, ki je zavezujoča za vse članice EU. Če ima človek edino streho nad glavo, čeprav je to nedovoljena gradnja, se mu ne sme rušiti. Hkrati je pomenljivo tudi to, da je po tem, ko so zravnali s tlemi moj dom, začel veljati moratorij na rušenje črnih gradenj. Vse velike živine z nelegalnimi objekti so rešile svoje nepremičnine v naslednjem obdobju, jaz pa sem postal socialni problem.«Šest let je minilo, šest dolgih let, kar Darko Kuzmič terja pravico in predvsem košček dostojanstva, ki mu je bil na današnji dan točno ob 13. uri, ko je policija od objekta odstranila protestnike in se je začelo rušenje, grobo poteptano.Račun za rušenje preklicali!Tik pred božičnimi prazniki leta 2013 je Darko Kuzmič prejel račun za rušenje hiške, ki je znašal skoraj 18.000 evrov. Ni se pritožil, saj je vedel, da mu nimajo kaj vzeti. Po dveh letih je prejel uradno obvestilo, da je račun preklican. Kdo je plačal rušenje? »Jaz ga nisem. Vsak črnograditelj mora plačati rušitev, meni je ni bilo treba. Torej tudi po tej logiki sploh nisem črnograditelj, kajne?« pravi Kuzmič.
text:
Six years have passed since his home fell
On November 5, 2013, Darko Kuzmic was left homeless and the demolitions ended.
05 Nov 2019, 06:50 by Boštjan Fon



Demolition began at exactly 1pm. PHOTO: Boštjan Fon



Darko Kuzmic is seeking EUR 100,000 in damages. PHOTO: Boštjan Fon



Today, there is no trace of the bungalows erected by the Rhine country. PHOTO: Boštjan Fon



Darko Kuzmic in front of his home the day before the demolition. PHOTO: Boštjan Fon



The protesters were driven away by police. PHOTO: Boštjan Fon


RIBČEV LAZ - Exactly six years ago, on November 5, 2013, at 9 o'clock, inspection services, with the support of the police cordon, headed to a modest wooden house called Ribčev laz 63 near the shore of Lake Bohinj. The most famous demolition of the home, the facility that was Darko Kuzmic's only residence, began. He was assigned to the post when he was appointed head of the home adaptation of the Union of Socialist Youth of Slovenia (ZSMS) in Bohinj, today the Center for School and Extracurricular Activities (CŠOD). The lodge has been standing here since 1965, with ten more of the same bungalows that are no longer available today.


Darko Kuzmic is seeking EUR 100,000 in damages. PHOTO: Boštjan Fon

Darko Kuzmich did not construct the house arbitrarily, without permits, but the facilities were built by the then state. The current state, born of the one that designed the roof for Kuzmic, decided to demolish the building because it was a black construction, although it was erected by its predecessor and not the bohemian end of Prekmurec. It was in this controversial bungalow, which was demolished six years ago today, that Kuzmic was home to a hotel director. Two days before his 60th birthday, Kuzmic became another social problem on the sunny side of the Alps.


Darko Kuzmic in front of his home the day before the demolition. PHOTO: Boštjan Fon

Without understanding the municipality of Bohinj, it would have to be literally under the nearby big spruce before the winter, so they were given an apartment in an old school in Gorjuše, where it still lives today. "You could really only go under the spruce, but because of the new building, you are no longer there," Kuzmic describes the bizarreness of the whole affair. Immediately after independence, he paid SIT 250,000 at the time, thinking that he would be able to arrange the papers and buy the house. So today is the sixth year without it.


Today, there is no trace of the bungalows erected by the Rhine country. PHOTO: Boštjan Fon

The Ljubljana District Court is currently pursuing a lawsuit, in which Kuzmic is seeking damages of EUR 100,000 from the state and the current Central School for the demolition of the facility. Kuzmic is convinced that the log cabin should not be torn down because it was his home. “They knew about the decision of the European Court of Human Rights in the field of illegal construction, which is binding on all EU members. If a person has the only roof over his head, even if it is unauthorized construction, he should not collapse. At the same time, it is also significant that, after they flattened my home, a moratorium on the demolition of black structures came into force. All large cattle with illegal facilities solved their real estate in the next period, and I became a social problem. "Six years have passed, six long years, which requires Darko Kuzmic to claim the right and, above all, the piece of dignity he was given today. 13:00, when the police removed the protesters from the building and demolition began, roughly trampled. The demolition account was canceled! Just before the Christmas holidays in 2013, Darko Kuzmic received a bill for demolishing the house, which amounted to almost € 18,000. He did not complain, knowing that they had nothing to take from him. After two years, he received a notification that the account had been canceled. Who paid for the demolition? “I didn't. Every black builder had to pay for the demolition, I didn't have to. So even by that logic, I'm not a black builder at all, right? "Kuzmic says.
